A very good book should take you apart before it puts you back together again.
I have a little trouble describing just what makes a bad book bad. It's hard to quantify the things that I don't like about books I didn't like because, of course, the reasons can be so varied.
It doesn't take much for me to put down a book. If it's hard to follow the plot, if the characters are confusing or just plain unlikable, if the story moves too slowly, if the prose is overly dense or clumsy, I've got no problem closing it and moving on to the next one. Sometimes I get the feeling from a book that it's trying too hard to impress, and that's often a turn-off. Sometimes a book that's clearly a genre exercise simply doesn't offer me anything new or fresh within its pages, and I'm happy to abandon it.
Often, of course, the problem with a bad book can be traced to sloppy editing (if it's been edited at all). Typos, factual errors, inconsistencies, poor formatting, and grammatical errors can all combine to make a book hard to read and frustrating to attempt to review. If you're going to ask people to pay money for your work, it seems reasonable that the work should be as polished and well-crafted as you can make it. But every week I seem to run across books that are self-published or from small presses that seem to have been dashed off with little or no editing or revising.
So those are a few things that can make a book bad. Not as clearly defined as what makes a good book good, granted, but the negative can be a little more difficult to pin down.
What qualities make a book bad, for you, specifically? What are some deal-breaker traits or events for your reading experience?

This was back in the good ole days of 2005, when I was doing my mod, Wastelands of Eden. It's not a great mod, but it was my first one and I'm proud of it. Also, at the time I was doing this for fun and just to see if I could build something from scratch. I was using the Oblivion tools, so I also found myself frequently visiting the Bethesda Forums where I saw someone was looking for help getting a mod done. He was really bad at scripting, but had the idea, and resources, so I agreed to help. Turned out that he lived relatively nearby, in Virginia, so I thought it would be fun to drive over and meet him, have a face to face talk about the mod and play some Oblivion.
This is the guy we are talking about. We'll call him Jim Bob, because that's a good American name, and it's also the name I've used countless times for other people, so why not.
Jim Bob is an older guy, maybe late 40s or early 50s and has a bit of a belly. He always wears jeans and some kind of a camo shirt. He lives in an apartment that's a bit dirty. The first thing we do when I get there is fire up some Oblivion co-op and play for a bit - which was always fun in a game that was not really designed for multiplayer.
After a couple of hours playing, we decide to order some pizza and have a talk about the mod while we eat. We are deep in mod-talk when Jim Bob suddenly says, "Hey, I'll be right back, I need to use the bathroom."
"Sure, go ahead, I'll keep playing while you're out. " I reply, and get back to playing.
About 20 or 30 seconds after Jim Bob leaves the room, I hear the toilet flush in the bathroom. I think to myself, "Huh, he must have REALLY had to go", and get back to playing.
Another few seconds pass, and I suddenly hear something strange coming from the bathroom - something that made me freeze.
I heard Jim Bob talking. He was talking to himself.
Not really saying anything, just talking. It was a low, monotone voice like when you're talking to a 2 year old. "Bubbles are fun. Bubbles make you happy. Squeaky toys are fun. Squeaky toys make you happy."
Now, I'm not a doctor, but as a layman, this was NOT normal. And just like that, he stopped talking and comes out of the bathroom like nothing had happened. We resumed our conversation about the mod after he apologized for taking a bit longer than expected in the bathroom.
The moment passes, but something just felt very "off". I kept thinking about the talking while I was playing and eating pizza. I finally decided that perhaps it was time to wrap things up, because I had a long drive back home ahead of me. I could tell Jim Bob was a bit upset that I didn't want to stay longer, but I said that I had some things to do and had to get back home. I left his apartment and started the long drive home.
I didn't think much about the talking thing over the next few weeks, although I did keep an eye on my backseat just in case Jim Bob decided to hitch a ride back home with me. After a couple of weeks, I got an email from Jim Bob. In it, he said that he needed some help with some more advanced scripting in the mod, and offered to pay me to work for him for a weekend. That morning, I drove to his apartment and found he was a bit more prepared for my visit. He had pizza and soda waiting for us and we started working on the advanced scripting. Finally, after about 4 hours of working, I decided I had enough. I told Jim Bob I was done for the day, and would finish up in the morning. He seemed a bit miffed, but agreed, so I left the apartment, got in my car and started driving
